title: 109_hr3492
content: The Consumer Credit Card Protection Act of 2005 prohibits universal defaults on credit card accounts. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits creditors from using adverse information to increase interest rates on credit card accounts, as well as from removing or increasing introductory rates for reasons unrelated to consumer actions. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits creditors from using adverse information to increase interest rates on credit card accounts. Credit card issuers must clearly inform consumers about this limitation in any required disclosures or statements. SEC. 3. BOX DISCLOSURE OF PAYMENT PERIOD FOR MINIMUM PAYMENTS ON CREDIT CARD BALANCE. Section 127(b) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card balances. This includes clear and conspicuous repayment information in a tabular format, showing the required minimum monthly payment as a dollar figure and percentage of the outstanding balance, along with the estimated number of months to pay off the balance. The Truth in Lending Act now includes new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card balances, with clear repayment information in a tabular format. This includes showing the required minimum monthly payment as a dollar figure and percentage of the outstanding balance, along with the estimated number of months to pay off the balance. The creditor must apply any applicable APR in making determinations for these disclosures. The creditor must apply the applicable annual percentage rate of interest in effect on the date of disclosure, considering different rates for various outstanding balance portions, regardless of fixed or variable rates. When disclosing a temporary or introductory rate subject to change based on an index or formula, the creditor must use the current annual percentage rate for the introductory period and an adjusted rate for subsequent adjustments. The creditor must use the current annual percentage rate for the introductory period when disclosing a temporary or introductory rate subject to change based on an index or formula. SEC. 4. ADVANCED NOTICE REQUIRED BEFORE INCREASING RATES OR FEES ON CREDIT CARD ACCOUNTS. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to require advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts. No rate increase can take effect before the beginning of the billing cycle that starts at least 30 days after the obligor receives a specific notice. The Truth in Lending Act now requires advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts. The obligor must receive a specific notice of the rate increase at least 30 days before it can take effect. If the rate increase is solely due to a change in another indexed rate, it takes effect after 30 days. If not, it takes effect after 60 days. The creditor can apply the new rate to any outstanding balance. The Truth in Lending Act requires advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts. No fees can be imposed before the end of a 30-day period after the obligor receives a specific notice of the fee. The notice must be mailed or e-mailed separately from any other communication. The Truth in Lending Act mandates advance notice of fee increases on credit card accounts. The notice must be sent separately from other communications, with an explanation of when, why, and how fees will be imposed, and options for addressing them.
